# Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations

Yang Song

Stanford University

yangsong@cs.stanford.edu

&Jascha Sohl-Dickstein

Google Brain

jaschasd@google.com

&Diederik P. Kingma

Google Brain

durk@google.com

\\ANDAbhishek Kumar

Google Brain

abhishk@google.com

&Stefano Ermon

Stanford University

ermon@cs.stanford.edu

&Ben Poole

Google Brain

pooleb@google.comWork partially done during an internship at Google Brain.

###### Abstract

Creating noise from data is easy; creating data from noise is generative modeling. We present a stochastic differential equation (SDE) that smoothly transforms a complex data distribution to a known prior distribution by slowly injecting noise, and a corresponding reverse-time SDE that transforms the prior distribution back into the data distribution by slowly removing the noise.
Crucially, the reverse-time SDE depends only on the time-dependent gradient field (a.k.a., score) of the perturbed data distribution. By leveraging advances in score-based generative modeling, we can accurately estimate these scores with neural networks, and use numerical SDE solvers to generate samples. We show that this framework encapsulates previous approaches in score-based generative modeling and diffusion probabilistic modeling, allowing for new sampling procedures and new modeling capabilities. In particular, we introduce a predictor-corrector framework to correct errors in the evolution of the discretized reverse-time SDE. We also derive an equivalent neural ODE that samples from the same distribution as the SDE, but additionally enables exact likelihood computation, and improved sampling efficiency. In addition, we provide a new way to solve inverse problems with score-based models,
as demonstrated with experiments on class-conditional generation, image inpainting, and colorization. Combined with multiple architectural improvements, we achieve record-breaking performance for unconditional image generation on CIFAR-10 with an Inception score of 9.89 and FID of 2.20, a competitive likelihood of 2.99 bits/dim, and demonstrate high fidelity generation of 1024×1024102410241024\\times 1024 images for the first time from a score-based generative model.

## 1 Introduction

Two successful classes of probabilistic generative models involve sequentially corrupting training data with slowly increasing noise, and then learning to reverse this corruption in order to form a generative model of the data.
_Score matching with Langevin dynamics_ (SMLD) (Song & Ermon, [2019](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib43 "")) estimates the _score_ ( _i.e_., the gradient of the log probability density with respect to data) at each noise scale, and then uses Langevin dynamics to sample from a sequence of decreasing noise scales during generation.
_Denoising diffusion probabilistic modeling_ (DDPM) (Sohl-Dickstein et al., [2015](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib42 ""); Ho et al., [2020](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib19 "")) trains a sequence of probabilistic models to reverse each step of the noise corruption,
using knowledge of the functional form of the reverse distributions to make training tractable.
For continuous state spaces, the DDPM training objective implicitly computes
scores at each noise scale.
We therefore refer to these two model classes together as _score-based generative models_.

Score-based generative models, and related techniques (Bordes et al., [2017](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib4 ""); Goyal et al., [2017](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib15 ""); Du & Mordatch, [2019](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib12 "")), have proven effective at generation of images (Song & Ermon, [2019](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib43 ""); [2020](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib44 ""); Ho et al., [2020](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib19 "")), audio (Chen et al., [2020](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib7 ""); Kong et al., [2020](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib29 "")), graphs (Niu et al., [2020](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib34 "")), and shapes (Cai et al., [2020](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib6 "")). To enable new sampling methods and further extend the capabilities of score-based generative models, we propose a unified framework that generalizes previous approaches through the lens of stochastic differential equations (SDEs).

Figure 1: Solving a reverse-time SDE yields a score-based generative model. Transforming data to a simple noise distribution can be accomplished with a continuous-time SDE. This SDE can be reversed if we know the score of the distribution at each intermediate time step, ∇𝐱log⁡pt​(𝐱)subscript∇𝐱subscript𝑝𝑡𝐱\\nabla\_{\\mathbf{x}}\\log p\_{t}(\\mathbf{x}). ![Refer to caption](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456/assets/x1.png)

Specifically, instead of perturbing data with a finite number of noise distributions, we consider a continuum of distributions that evolve over time according to a diffusion process. This process progressively diffuses a data point into random noise, and is given by a prescribed SDE that does not depend on the data and has no trainable parameters.
By reversing this process, we can smoothly mold random noise into data for sample generation. Crucially, this reverse process satisfies a reverse-time SDE (Anderson, [1982](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib2 "")), which can be derived from the forward SDE given the score of the marginal probability densities as a function of time. We can therefore approximate the reverse-time SDE by training a time-dependent neural network to estimate the scores, and then produce samples using numerical SDE solvers. Our key idea is summarized in [Fig.1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S1.F1 "In 1 Introduction ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations").

Our proposed framework has several theoretical and practical contributions:

Flexible sampling and likelihood computation:  We can employ any general-purpose SDE solver to integrate the reverse-time SDE for sampling. In addition, we propose two special methods not viable for general SDEs: (i) Predictor-Corrector (PC) samplers that combine numerical SDE solvers with score-based MCMC approaches, such as Langevin MCMC (Parisi, [1981](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib37 "")) and HMC (Neal et al., [2011](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib33 "")); and (ii) deterministic samplers based on the probability flow ordinary differential equation (ODE). The former _unifies and improves_ over existing sampling methods for score-based models. The latter allows for _fast adaptive sampling_ via black-box ODE solvers, _flexible data manipulation_ via latent codes, a _uniquely identifiable encoding_, and notably, _exact likelihood computation_.

Controllable generation:  We can modulate the generation process by conditioning on information not available during training, because the conditional reverse-time SDE can be efficiently estimated from _unconditional_ scores. This enables applications such as class-conditional generation, image inpainting, colorization and other inverse problems, all achievable using a single unconditional score-based model without re-training.

Unified framework:  Our framework provides a unified way to explore and tune various SDEs for improving score-based generative models.
The methods of SMLD and DDPM can be amalgamated into our framework as discretizations of two separate SDEs.
Although DDPM (Ho et al., [2020](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib19 "")) was recently reported to achieve higher sample quality than SMLD (Song & Ermon, [2019](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib43 ""); [2020](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib44 "")), we show that with better architectures and new sampling algorithms allowed by our framework, the latter can catch up—it achieves new state-of-the-art Inception score (9.89) and FID score (2.20) on CIFAR-10, as well as high-fidelity generation of 1024×1024102410241024\\times 1024 images for the first time from a score-based model. In addition, we propose a new SDE under our framework that achieves a likelihood value of 2.99 bits/dim on uniformly dequantized CIFAR-10 images, setting a new record on this task.

Notably, the weights of the i𝑖i-th summand in [Eq.1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S2.E1 "In 2.1 Denoising score matching with Langevin dynamics (SMLD) ‣ 2 Background ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations") and [Eq.3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S2.E3 "In 2.2 Denoising diffusion probabilistic models (DDPM) ‣ 2 Background ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"), namely σi2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖2\\sigma\_{i}^{2} and (1−αi)1subscript𝛼𝑖(1-\\alpha\_{i}), are related to corresponding perturbation kernels in the same functional form: σi2∝1/𝔼​\[∥∇𝐱log⁡pσi​(𝐱~∣𝐱)∥22\]proportional-tosuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖21𝔼delimited-\[\]superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript∇𝐱subscript𝑝subscript𝜎𝑖conditional~𝐱𝐱22\\sigma\_{i}^{2}\\propto 1/\\mathbb{E}\[\\left\\lVert\\nabla\_{\\mathbf{x}}\\log p\_{\\sigma\_{i}}(\\tilde{\\mathbf{x}}\\mid\\mathbf{x})\\right\\rVert\_{2}^{2}\] and (1−αi)∝1/𝔼​\[∥∇𝐱log⁡pαi​(𝐱~∣𝐱)∥22\]proportional-to1subscript𝛼𝑖1𝔼delimited-\[\]superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript∇𝐱subscript𝑝subscript𝛼𝑖conditional~𝐱𝐱22(1-\\alpha\_{i})\\propto 1/\\mathbb{E}\[\\left\\lVert\\nabla\_{\\mathbf{x}}\\log p\_{\\alpha\_{i}}(\\tilde{\\mathbf{x}}\\mid\\mathbf{x})\\right\\rVert\_{2}^{2}\].

## 3 Score-based generative modeling with SDEs

Perturbing data with multiple noise scales is key to the success of previous methods. We propose to generalize this idea further to an infinite number of noise scales, such that perturbed data distributions evolve according to an SDE as the noise intensifies. An overview of our framework is given in [Fig.2](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S3.F2 "In 3 Score-based generative modeling with SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations").

![Refer to caption](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456/assets/x2.png)Figure 2: Overview of score-based generative modeling through SDEs. We can map data to a noise distribution (the prior) with an SDE ( [Section3.1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S3.SS1 "3.1 Perturbing data with SDEs ‣ 3 Score-based generative modeling with SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")), and reverse this SDE for generative modeling ( [Section3.2](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S3.SS2 "3.2 Generating samples by reversing the SDE ‣ 3 Score-based generative modeling with SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")). We can also reverse the associated probability flow ODE ( [Section4.3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S4.SS3 "4.3 Probability flow and connection to neural ODEs ‣ 4 Solving the reverse SDE ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")), which yields a deterministic process that samples from the same distribution as the SDE. Both the reverse-time SDE and probability flow ODE can be obtained by estimating the score ∇𝐱log⁡pt​(𝐱)subscript∇𝐱subscript𝑝𝑡𝐱\\nabla\_{\\mathbf{x}}\\log p\_{t}(\\mathbf{x}) ( [Section3.3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S3.SS3 "3.3 Estimating scores for the SDE ‣ 3 Score-based generative modeling with SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")).

### 3.1 Perturbing data with SDEs

Our goal is to construct a diffusion process {𝐱​(t)}t=0Tsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑡𝑡0𝑇\\{\\mathbf{x}(t)\\}\_{t=0}^{T} indexed by a continuous time variable t∈\[0,T\]𝑡0𝑇t\\in\[0,T\], such that 𝐱​(0)∼p0similar-to𝐱0subscript𝑝0\\mathbf{x}(0)\\sim p\_{0}, for which we have a dataset of i.i.d. samples, and 𝐱​(T)∼pTsimilar-to𝐱𝑇subscript𝑝𝑇\\mathbf{x}(T)\\sim p\_{T}, for which we have a tractable form to generate samples efficiently. In other words, p0subscript𝑝0p\_{0} is the data distribution and pTsubscript𝑝𝑇p\_{T} is the prior distribution. This diffusion process can be modeled as the solution to an Itô SDE:

|     |     |     |     |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
|  | d​𝐱=𝐟​(𝐱,t)​d​t+g​(t)​d​𝐰,d𝐱𝐟𝐱𝑡d𝑡𝑔𝑡d𝐰\\displaystyle\\mathrm{d}\\mathbf{x}=\\mathbf{f}(\\mathbf{x},t)\\mathrm{d}t+{g}(t)\\mathrm{d}\\mathbf{w}, |  | (5) |

where 𝐰𝐰\\mathbf{w} is the standard Wiener process (a.k.a., Brownian motion), 𝐟​(⋅,t):ℝd→ℝd:𝐟⋅𝑡→superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑\\mathbf{f}(\\cdot,t):\\mathbb{R}^{d}\\to\\mathbb{R}^{d} is a vector-valued function called the _drift_ coefficient of 𝐱​(t)𝐱𝑡\\mathbf{x}(t), and g​(⋅):ℝ→ℝ:𝑔⋅→ℝℝ{g}(\\cdot):\\mathbb{R}\\to\\mathbb{R} is a scalar function known as the _diffusion_ coefficient of 𝐱​(t)𝐱𝑡\\mathbf{x}(t). For ease of presentation we assume the diffusion coefficient is a scalar (instead of a d×d𝑑𝑑d\\times d matrix) and does not depend on 𝐱𝐱\\mathbf{x}, but our theory can be generalized to hold in those cases (see [AppendixA](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A1 "Appendix A The framework for more general SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")). The SDE has a unique strong solution as long as the coefficients are globally Lipschitz in both state and time (Øksendal, [2003](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib35 "")). We hereafter denote by pt​(𝐱)subscript𝑝𝑡𝐱p\_{t}(\\mathbf{x}) the probability density of 𝐱​(t)𝐱𝑡\\mathbf{x}(t), and use ps​t​(𝐱​(t)∣𝐱​(s))subscript𝑝𝑠𝑡conditional𝐱𝑡𝐱𝑠p\_{st}(\\mathbf{x}(t)\\mid\\mathbf{x}(s)) to denote the transition kernel from 𝐱​(s)𝐱𝑠\\mathbf{x}(s) to 𝐱​(t)𝐱𝑡\\mathbf{x}(t), where 0≤s<t≤T0𝑠𝑡𝑇0\\leq s<t\\leq T.

Typically, pTsubscript𝑝𝑇p\_{T} is an unstructured prior distribution that contains no information of p0subscript𝑝0p\_{0}, such as a Gaussian distribution with fixed mean and variance. There are various ways of designing the SDE in [Eq.5](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S3.E5 "In 3.1 Perturbing data with SDEs ‣ 3 Score-based generative modeling with SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations") such that it diffuses the data distribution into a fixed prior distribution. We provide several examples later in [Section3.4](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S3.SS4 "3.4 Examples: VE, VP SDEs and beyond ‣ 3 Score-based generative modeling with SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations") that are derived from continuous generalizations of SMLD and DDPM.

### 3.2 Generating samples by reversing the SDE

By starting from samples of 𝐱​(T)∼pTsimilar-to𝐱𝑇subscript𝑝𝑇\\mathbf{x}(T)\\sim p\_{T} and reversing the process, we can obtain samples 𝐱​(0)∼p0similar-to𝐱0subscript𝑝0\\mathbf{x}(0)\\sim p\_{0}. A remarkable result from Anderson ( [1982](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib2 "")) states that the reverse of a diffusion process is also a diffusion process, running backwards in time and given by the reverse-time SDE:

|     |     |     |     |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
|  | d​𝐱=\[𝐟​(𝐱,t)−g​(t)2​∇𝐱log⁡pt​(𝐱)\]​d​t+g​(t)​d​𝐰¯,d𝐱delimited-\[\]𝐟𝐱𝑡𝑔superscript𝑡2subscript∇𝐱subscript𝑝𝑡𝐱d𝑡𝑔𝑡d¯𝐰\\displaystyle\\mathrm{d}\\mathbf{x}=\[\\mathbf{f}(\\mathbf{x},t)-g(t)^{2}\\nabla\_{\\mathbf{x}}\\log p\_{t}(\\mathbf{x})\]\\mathrm{d}t+g(t)\\mathrm{d}\\bar{\\mathbf{w}}, |  | (6) |

where 𝐰¯¯𝐰\\bar{\\mathbf{w}} is a standard Wiener process
when time flows backwards from T𝑇T to 00, and d​td𝑡\\mathrm{d}t is an infinitesimal negative timestep. Once the score of each marginal distribution, ∇𝐱log⁡pt​(𝐱)subscript∇𝐱subscript𝑝𝑡𝐱\\nabla\_{\\mathbf{x}}\\log p\_{t}(\\mathbf{x}), is known for all t𝑡t, we can derive the reverse diffusion process from [Eq.6](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S3.E6 "In 3.2 Generating samples by reversing the SDE ‣ 3 Score-based generative modeling with SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations") and simulate it to sample from p0subscript𝑝0p\_{0}.

### 3.3 Estimating scores for the SDE

The score of a distribution can be estimated by training a score-based model on samples with score matching (Hyvärinen, [2005](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib21 ""); Song et al., [2019a](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib45 "")). To estimate ∇𝐱log⁡pt​(𝐱)subscript∇𝐱subscript𝑝𝑡𝐱\\nabla\_{\\mathbf{x}}\\log p\_{t}(\\mathbf{x}), we can train a time-dependent score-based model 𝐬𝜽​(𝐱,t)subscript𝐬𝜽𝐱𝑡\\mathbf{s}\_{\\boldsymbol{\\theta}}(\\mathbf{x},t) via a continuous generalization to [Eqs.1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S2.E1 "In 2.1 Denoising score matching with Langevin dynamics (SMLD) ‣ 2 Background ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations") and [3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S2.E3 "Equation 3 ‣ 2.2 Denoising diffusion probabilistic models (DDPM) ‣ 2 Background ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"):

|     |     |     |     |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
|  | 𝜽∗=arg​min𝜽⁡𝔼t​{λ​(t)​𝔼𝐱​(0)​𝔼𝐱​(t)∣𝐱​(0)​\[∥𝐬𝜽​(𝐱​(t),t)−∇𝐱​(t)log⁡p0​t​(𝐱​(t)∣𝐱​(0))∥22\]}.superscript𝜽subscriptargmin𝜽subscript𝔼𝑡𝜆𝑡subscript𝔼𝐱0subscript𝔼conditional𝐱𝑡𝐱0delimited-\[\]superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐬𝜽𝐱𝑡𝑡subscript∇𝐱𝑡subscript𝑝0𝑡conditional𝐱𝑡𝐱022\\displaystyle{\\boldsymbol{\\theta}}^{\*}=\\operatorname\*{arg\\,min}\_{\\boldsymbol{\\theta}}\\mathbb{E}\_{t}\\Big{\\{}\\lambda(t)\\mathbb{E}\_{\\mathbf{x}(0)}\\mathbb{E}\_{\\mathbf{x}(t)\\mid\\mathbf{x}(0)}\\big{\[}\\left\\lVert\\mathbf{s}\_{\\boldsymbol{\\theta}}(\\mathbf{x}(t),t)-\\nabla\_{\\mathbf{x}(t)}\\log p\_{0t}(\\mathbf{x}(t)\\mid\\mathbf{x}(0))\\right\\rVert\_{2}^{2}\\big{\]}\\Big{\\}}. |  | (7) |

Here λ:\[0,T\]→ℝ>0:𝜆→0𝑇subscriptℝabsent0\\lambda:\[0,T\]\\to\\mathbb{R}\_{>0} is a positive weighting function, t𝑡t is uniformly sampled over \[0,T\]0𝑇\[0,T\], 𝐱​(0)∼p0​(𝐱)similar-to𝐱0subscript𝑝0𝐱\\mathbf{x}(0)\\sim p\_{0}(\\mathbf{x}) and 𝐱​(t)∼p0​t​(𝐱​(t)∣𝐱​(0))similar-to𝐱𝑡subscript𝑝0𝑡conditional𝐱𝑡𝐱0\\mathbf{x}(t)\\sim p\_{0t}(\\mathbf{x}(t)\\mid\\mathbf{x}(0)). With sufficient data and model capacity, score matching ensures that the optimal solution to [Eq.7](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S3.E7 "In 3.3 Estimating scores for the SDE ‣ 3 Score-based generative modeling with SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"), denoted by 𝐬𝜽∗​(𝐱,t)subscript𝐬superscript𝜽∗𝐱𝑡\\mathbf{s}\_{{\\boldsymbol{\\theta}}^{\\ast}}(\\mathbf{x},t), equals ∇𝐱log⁡pt​(𝐱)subscript∇𝐱subscript𝑝𝑡𝐱\\nabla\_{\\mathbf{x}}\\log p\_{t}(\\mathbf{x}) for almost all 𝐱𝐱\\mathbf{x} and t𝑡t. As in SMLD and DDPM, we can typically choose λ∝1/𝔼​\[∥∇𝐱​(t)log⁡p0​t​(𝐱​(t)∣𝐱​(0))∥22\]proportional-to𝜆1𝔼delimited-\[\]superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript∇𝐱𝑡subscript𝑝0𝑡conditional𝐱𝑡𝐱022\\lambda\\propto 1/{\\mathbb{E}\\big{\[}\\left\\lVert\\nabla\_{\\mathbf{x}(t)}\\log p\_{0t}(\\mathbf{x}(t)\\mid\\mathbf{x}(0))\\right\\rVert\_{2}^{2}\\big{\]}}. Note that [Eq.7](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S3.E7 "In 3.3 Estimating scores for the SDE ‣ 3 Score-based generative modeling with SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations") uses denoising score matching, but other score matching objectives, such as sliced score matching (Song et al., [2019a](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib45 "")) and finite-difference score matching (Pang et al., [2020](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib36 "")) are also applicable here.

We typically need to know the transition kernel p0​t​(𝐱​(t)∣𝐱​(0))subscript𝑝0𝑡conditional𝐱𝑡𝐱0p\_{0t}(\\mathbf{x}(t)\\mid\\mathbf{x}(0)) to efficiently solve [Eq.7](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S3.E7 "In 3.3 Estimating scores for the SDE ‣ 3 Score-based generative modeling with SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"). When 𝐟​(⋅,t)𝐟⋅𝑡\\mathbf{f}(\\cdot,t) is affine, the transition kernel is always a Gaussian distribution, where the mean and variance are often known in closed-forms and can be obtained with standard techniques (see Section 5.5 in Särkkä & Solin ( [2019](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib40 ""))). For more general SDEs, we may solve Kolmogorov’s forward equation (Øksendal, [2003](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib35 "")) to obtain p0​t​(𝐱​(t)∣𝐱​(0))subscript𝑝0𝑡conditional𝐱𝑡𝐱0p\_{0t}(\\mathbf{x}(t)\\mid\\mathbf{x}(0)). Alternatively, we can simulate the SDE to sample from p0​t​(𝐱​(t)∣𝐱​(0))subscript𝑝0𝑡conditional𝐱𝑡𝐱0p\_{0t}(\\mathbf{x}(t)\\mid\\mathbf{x}(0)) and replace denoising score matching in [Eq.7](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S3.E7 "In 3.3 Estimating scores for the SDE ‣ 3 Score-based generative modeling with SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations") with sliced score matching for model training, which bypasses the computation of ∇𝐱​(t)log⁡p0​t​(𝐱​(t)∣𝐱​(0))subscript∇𝐱𝑡subscript𝑝0𝑡conditional𝐱𝑡𝐱0\\nabla\_{\\mathbf{x}(t)}\\log p\_{0t}(\\mathbf{x}(t)\\mid\\mathbf{x}(0)) (see [AppendixA](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A1 "Appendix A The framework for more general SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")).

### 3.4 Examples: VE, VP SDEs and beyond

The noise perturbations used in SMLD and DDPM can be regarded as discretizations of two different SDEs. Below we provide a brief discussion and relegate more details to [AppendixB](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A2 "Appendix B VE, VP and sub-VP SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations").

When using a total of N𝑁N noise scales, each perturbation kernel pσi​(𝐱∣𝐱0)subscript𝑝subscript𝜎𝑖conditional𝐱subscript𝐱0p\_{\\sigma\_{i}}(\\mathbf{x}\\mid\\mathbf{x}\_{0}) of SMLD corresponds to the distribution of 𝐱isubscript𝐱𝑖\\mathbf{x}\_{i} in the following Markov chain:

|     |     |     |     |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
|  | 𝐱i=𝐱i−1+σi2−σi−12​𝐳i−1,i=1,⋯,N,formulae-sequencesubscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝐱𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖12subscript𝐳𝑖1𝑖1⋯𝑁\\displaystyle\\mathbf{x}\_{i}=\\mathbf{x}\_{i-1}+\\sqrt{\\sigma\_{i}^{2}-\\sigma\_{i-1}^{2}}\\mathbf{z}\_{i-1},\\quad i=1,\\cdots,N, |  | (8) |

where 𝐳i−1∼𝒩​(𝟎,𝐈)similar-tosubscript𝐳𝑖1𝒩0𝐈\\mathbf{z}\_{i-1}\\sim\\mathcal{N}(\\mathbf{0},\\mathbf{I}), and we have introduced σ0=0subscript𝜎00\\sigma\_{0}=0 to simplify the notation.
In the limit of N→∞→𝑁N\\to\\infty, {σi}i=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖𝑖1𝑁\\{\\sigma\_{i}\\}\_{i=1}^{N} becomes a function σ​(t)𝜎𝑡\\sigma(t), 𝐳isubscript𝐳𝑖\\mathbf{z}\_{i} becomes 𝐳​(t)𝐳𝑡\\mathbf{z}(t), and the Markov chain {𝐱i}i=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑖1𝑁\\{\\mathbf{x}\_{i}\\}\_{i=1}^{N} becomes a continuous stochastic process {𝐱​(t)}t=01superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑡𝑡01\\{\\mathbf{x}(t)\\}\_{t=0}^{1}, where we have used a continuous time variable t∈\[0,1\]𝑡01t\\in\[0,1\] for indexing, rather than an integer i𝑖i. The process {𝐱​(t)}t=01superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑡𝑡01\\{\\mathbf{x}(t)\\}\_{t=0}^{1} is given by the following SDE

|     |     |     |     |

|  | d​𝐱=d​\[σ2​(t)\]d​t​d​𝐰.d𝐱ddelimited-\[\]superscript𝜎2𝑡d𝑡d𝐰\\displaystyle\\mathrm{d}\\mathbf{x}=\\sqrt{\\frac{\\mathrm{d}\\left\[\\sigma^{2}(t)\\right\]}{\\mathrm{d}t}}\\mathrm{d}\\mathbf{w}. |  | (9) |

Likewise for the perturbation kernels {pαi​(𝐱∣𝐱0)}i=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑝subscript𝛼𝑖conditional𝐱subscript𝐱0𝑖1𝑁\\{p\_{\\alpha\_{i}}(\\mathbf{x}\\mid\\mathbf{x}\_{0})\\}\_{i=1}^{N} of DDPM, the discrete Markov chain is

|     |     |     |     |

As N→∞→𝑁N\\to\\infty, [Eq.10](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S3.E10 "In 3.4 Examples: VE, VP SDEs and beyond ‣ 3 Score-based generative modeling with SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations") converges to the following SDE,

Therefore, the noise perturbations used in SMLD and DDPM correspond to discretizations of SDEs [Eqs.9](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S3.E9 "In 3.4 Examples: VE, VP SDEs and beyond ‣ 3 Score-based generative modeling with SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations") and [11](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S3.E11 "Equation 11 ‣ 3.4 Examples: VE, VP SDEs and beyond ‣ 3 Score-based generative modeling with SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"). Interestingly, the SDE of [Eq.9](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S3.E9 "In 3.4 Examples: VE, VP SDEs and beyond ‣ 3 Score-based generative modeling with SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations") always gives a process with exploding variance when t→∞→𝑡t\\to\\infty, whilst the SDE of [Eq.11](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S3.E11 "In 3.4 Examples: VE, VP SDEs and beyond ‣ 3 Score-based generative modeling with SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations") yields a process with a fixed variance of one when the initial distribution has unit variance (proof in [AppendixB](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A2 "Appendix B VE, VP and sub-VP SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")). Due to this difference, we hereafter refer to [Eq.9](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S3.E9 "In 3.4 Examples: VE, VP SDEs and beyond ‣ 3 Score-based generative modeling with SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations") as the Variance Exploding (VE) SDE, and [Eq.11](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S3.E11 "In 3.4 Examples: VE, VP SDEs and beyond ‣ 3 Score-based generative modeling with SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations") the Variance Preserving (VP) SDE.

Inspired by the VP SDE, we propose a new type of SDEs which perform particularly well on likelihoods (see [Section4.3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S4.SS3 "4.3 Probability flow and connection to neural ODEs ‣ 4 Solving the reverse SDE ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")), given by

|     |     |     |     |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
|  | d​𝐱=−12​β​(t)​𝐱​d​t+β​(t)​(1−e−2​∫0tβ​(s)​ds)​d​𝐰.d𝐱12𝛽𝑡𝐱d𝑡𝛽𝑡1superscript𝑒2superscriptsubscript0𝑡𝛽𝑠differential-d𝑠d𝐰\\displaystyle\\mathrm{d}\\mathbf{x}=-\\frac{1}{2}\\beta(t)\\mathbf{x}~{}\\mathrm{d}t+\\sqrt{\\beta(t)(1-e^{-2\\int\_{0}^{t}\\beta(s)\\mathrm{d}s})}\\mathrm{d}\\mathbf{w}. |  | (12) |

When using the same β​(t)𝛽𝑡\\beta(t) and starting from the same initial distribution, the variance of the stochastic process induced by [Eq.12](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S3.E12 "In 3.4 Examples: VE, VP SDEs and beyond ‣ 3 Score-based generative modeling with SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations") is always bounded by the VP SDE at every intermediate time step (proof in [AppendixB](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A2 "Appendix B VE, VP and sub-VP SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")). For this reason, we name [Eq.12](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S3.E12 "In 3.4 Examples: VE, VP SDEs and beyond ‣ 3 Score-based generative modeling with SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations") the sub-VP SDE.

Since VE, VP and sub-VP SDEs all have affine drift coefficients, their perturbation kernels p0​t​(𝐱​(t)∣𝐱​(0))subscript𝑝0𝑡conditional𝐱𝑡𝐱0p\_{0t}(\\mathbf{x}(t)\\mid\\mathbf{x}(0)) are all Gaussian and can be computed in closed-forms, as discussed in [Section3.3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S3.SS3 "3.3 Estimating scores for the SDE ‣ 3 Score-based generative modeling with SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"). This makes training with [Eq.7](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S3.E7 "In 3.3 Estimating scores for the SDE ‣ 3 Score-based generative modeling with SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations") particularly efficient.

## 4 Solving the reverse SDE

After training a time-dependent score-based model 𝐬𝜽subscript𝐬𝜽\\mathbf{s}\_{\\boldsymbol{\\theta}}, we can use it to construct the reverse-time SDE and then simulate it with numerical approaches to generate samples from p0subscript𝑝0p\_{0}.

### 4.1 General-purpose numerical SDE solvers

Numerical solvers provide approximate trajectories from SDEs. Many general-purpose numerical methods exist for solving SDEs, such as Euler-Maruyama and stochastic Runge-Kutta methods (Kloeden & Platen, [2013](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib28 "")), which correspond to different discretizations of the stochastic dynamics. We can apply any of them to the reverse-time SDE for sample generation.

Ancestral sampling, the sampling method of DDPM ( [Eq.4](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S2.E4 "In 2.2 Denoising diffusion probabilistic models (DDPM) ‣ 2 Background ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")), actually corresponds to one special discretization of the reverse-time VP SDE ( [Eq.11](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S3.E11 "In 3.4 Examples: VE, VP SDEs and beyond ‣ 3 Score-based generative modeling with SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")) (see [AppendixE](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A5 "Appendix E Reverse diffusion sampling ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")). Deriving the ancestral sampling rules for new SDEs, however, can be non-trivial. To remedy this, we propose _reverse diffusion samplers_ (details in [AppendixE](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A5 "Appendix E Reverse diffusion sampling ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")), which discretize the reverse-time SDE in the same way as the forward one, and thus can be readily derived given the forward discretization.
As shown in [Table1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S4.T1 "In 4.2 Predictor-corrector samplers ‣ 4 Solving the reverse SDE ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"), reverse diffusion samplers perform slightly better than ancestral sampling for both SMLD and DDPM models on CIFAR-10 (DDPM-type ancestral sampling is also applicable to SMLD models, see [AppendixF](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A6 "Appendix F Ancestral sampling for SMLD models ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations").)

### 4.2 Predictor-corrector samplers

Unlike generic SDEs, we have additional information that can be used to improve solutions. Since we have a score-based model 𝐬𝜽∗​(𝐱,t)≈∇𝐱log⁡pt​(𝐱)subscript𝐬superscript𝜽𝐱𝑡subscript∇𝐱subscript𝑝𝑡𝐱\\mathbf{s}\_{{\\boldsymbol{\\theta}}^{\*}}(\\mathbf{x},t)\\approx\\nabla\_{\\mathbf{x}}\\log p\_{t}(\\mathbf{x}), we can employ score-based MCMC approaches, such as Langevin MCMC (Parisi, [1981](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib37 ""); Grenander & Miller, [1994](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib17 "")) or HMC (Neal et al., [2011](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib33 "")) to sample from ptsubscript𝑝𝑡p\_{t} directly, and correct the solution of a numerical SDE solver.

Specifically, at each time step, the numerical SDE solver first gives an estimate of the sample at the next time step, playing the role of a “predictor”. Then, the score-based MCMC approach corrects the
marginal distribution of the estimated sample, playing the role of a “corrector”. The idea is analogous to Predictor-Corrector methods, a family of numerical continuation techniques for solving systems of equations (Allgower & Georg, [2012](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib1 "")), and we similarly name our hybrid sampling algorithms _Predictor-Corrector_ (PC) samplers. Please find pseudo-code and a complete description in [AppendixG](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A7 "Appendix G Predictor-Corrector samplers ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"). PC samplers generalize the original sampling methods of SMLD and DDPM: the former uses an identity function as the predictor and annealed Langevin dynamics as the corrector, while the latter uses ancestral sampling as the predictor and identity as the corrector.

We test PC samplers on SMLD and DDPM models (see [Algorithms2](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#alg2 "In Predictor-Corrector (PC) sampling ‣ Appendix G Predictor-Corrector samplers ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations") and [3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#alg3 "Algorithm 3 ‣ Predictor-Corrector (PC) sampling ‣ Appendix G Predictor-Corrector samplers ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations") in [AppendixG](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A7 "Appendix G Predictor-Corrector samplers ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")) trained with original discrete objectives given by [Eqs.1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S2.E1 "In 2.1 Denoising score matching with Langevin dynamics (SMLD) ‣ 2 Background ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations") and [3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S2.E3 "Equation 3 ‣ 2.2 Denoising diffusion probabilistic models (DDPM) ‣ 2 Background ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"). This exhibits the compatibility of PC samplers to score-based models trained with a fixed number of noise scales. We summarize the performance of different samplers in [Table1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S4.T1 "In 4.2 Predictor-corrector samplers ‣ 4 Solving the reverse SDE ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"), where probability flow is a predictor to be discussed in [Section4.3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S4.SS3 "4.3 Probability flow and connection to neural ODEs ‣ 4 Solving the reverse SDE ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"). Detailed experimental settings and additional results are given in [AppendixG](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A7 "Appendix G Predictor-Corrector samplers ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"). We observe that our reverse diffusion sampler always outperform ancestral sampling, and corrector-only methods (C2000) perform worse than other competitors (P2000, PC1000) with the same computation (In fact, we need way more corrector steps per noise scale, and thus more computation, to match the performance of other samplers.) For all predictors, adding one corrector step for each predictor step (PC1000) doubles computation but always improves sample quality (against P1000). Moreover, it is typically better than doubling the number of predictor steps without adding a corrector (P2000), where we have to interpolate between noise scales in an ad hoc manner (detailed in [AppendixG](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A7 "Appendix G Predictor-Corrector samplers ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")) for SMLD/DDPM models. In [Fig.9](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A7.F9 "In Denoising ‣ Appendix G Predictor-Corrector samplers ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations") ( [AppendixG](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A7 "Appendix G Predictor-Corrector samplers ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")), we additionally provide qualitative comparison for models trained with the continuous objective [Eq.7](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S3.E7 "In 3.3 Estimating scores for the SDE ‣ 3 Score-based generative modeling with SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations") on 256×256256256256\\times 256 LSUN images and the VE SDE, where PC samplers clearly surpass predictor-only samplers under comparable computation, when using a proper number of corrector steps.

### 4.3 Probability flow and connection to neural ODEs

Score-based models enable another numerical method for solving the reverse-time SDE. For all diffusion processes, there exists a corresponding _deterministic process_ whose trajectories share the same marginal probability densities {pt​(𝐱)}t=0Tsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑝𝑡𝐱𝑡0𝑇\\{p\_{t}(\\mathbf{x})\\}\_{t=0}^{T} as the SDE. This deterministic process satisfies an ODE (more details in [SectionD.1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A4.SS1 "D.1 Derivation ‣ Appendix D Probability flow ODE ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")):

|     |     |     |     |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
|  | d​𝐱=\[𝐟​(𝐱,t)−12​g​(t)2​∇𝐱log⁡pt​(𝐱)\]​d​t,d𝐱delimited-\[\]𝐟𝐱𝑡12𝑔superscript𝑡2subscript∇𝐱subscript𝑝𝑡𝐱d𝑡\\displaystyle\\mathrm{d}\\mathbf{x}=\\Big{\[}\\mathbf{f}(\\mathbf{x},t)-\\frac{1}{2}g(t)^{2}\\nabla\_{\\mathbf{x}}\\log p\_{t}(\\mathbf{x})\\Big{\]}\\mathrm{d}t, |  | (13) |

which can be determined from the SDE once scores are known. We name the ODE in [Eq.13](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S4.E13 "In 4.3 Probability flow and connection to neural ODEs ‣ 4 Solving the reverse SDE ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations") the _probability flow ODE_.
When the score function is approximated by the time-dependent score-based model, which is typically a neural network, this is an example of a neural ODE (Chen et al., [2018](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib8 "")).

Exact likelihood computation  Leveraging the connection to neural ODEs, we can compute the density defined by [Eq.13](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S4.E13 "In 4.3 Probability flow and connection to neural ODEs ‣ 4 Solving the reverse SDE ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations") via the instantaneous change of variables formula (Chen et al., [2018](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib8 "")). This allows us to compute the _exact likelihood on any input data_ (details in [SectionD.2](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A4.SS2 "D.2 Likelihood computation ‣ Appendix D Probability flow ODE ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")). As an example, we report negative log-likelihoods (NLLs) measured in bits/dim on the CIFAR-10 dataset in [Table2](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S4.T2 "In 4.3 Probability flow and connection to neural ODEs ‣ 4 Solving the reverse SDE ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"). We compute log-likelihoods on uniformly dequantized data, and only compare to models evaluated in the same way (omitting models evaluated with variational dequantization (Ho et al., [2019](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib18 "")) or discrete data), except for DDPM (L𝐿L/Lsimplesubscript𝐿simpleL\_{\\text{simple}}) whose ELBO values (annotated with \*) are reported on discrete data. Main results: (i) For the same DDPM model in Ho et al. ( [2020](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib19 "")), we obtain better bits/dim than ELBO, since our likelihoods are exact; (ii) Using the same architecture, we trained another DDPM model with the continuous objective in [Eq.7](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S3.E7 "In 3.3 Estimating scores for the SDE ‣ 3 Score-based generative modeling with SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations") ( _i.e_., DDPM cont.), which further improves the likelihood; (iii) With sub-VP SDEs, we always get higher likelihoods compared to VP SDEs; (iv) With improved architecture ( _i.e_., DDPM++ cont., details in [Section4.4](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S4.SS4 "4.4 Architecture improvements ‣ 4 Solving the reverse SDE ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")) and the sub-VP SDE, we can set a new record bits/dim of 2.99 on uniformly dequantized CIFAR-10 even _without maximum likelihood training_.

Manipulating latent representations  By integrating [Eq.13](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S4.E13 "In 4.3 Probability flow and connection to neural ODEs ‣ 4 Solving the reverse SDE ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"), we can encode any datapoint 𝐱​(0)𝐱0\\mathbf{x}(0) into a latent space 𝐱​(T)𝐱𝑇\\mathbf{x}(T). Decoding can be achieved by integrating a corresponding ODE for the reverse-time SDE. As is done with other invertible models such as neural ODEs and normalizing flows (Dinh et al., [2016](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib10 ""); Kingma & Dhariwal, [2018](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib27 "")), we can manipulate this latent representation for image editing, such as interpolation, and temperature scaling (see [Fig.3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S4.F3 "In 4.3 Probability flow and connection to neural ODEs ‣ 4 Solving the reverse SDE ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations") and [SectionD.4](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A4.SS4 "D.4 Sampling with black-box ODE solvers ‣ Appendix D Probability flow ODE ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")).

Uniquely identifiable encoding  Unlike most current invertible models,
our encoding is uniquely identifiable, meaning that with sufficient training data, model capacity, and optimization accuracy, the encoding for an input is uniquely determined by the data distribution (Roeder et al., [2020](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib39 "")). This is because our forward SDE, [Eq.5](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S3.E5 "In 3.1 Perturbing data with SDEs ‣ 3 Score-based generative modeling with SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"), has no trainable parameters, and its associated probability flow ODE, [Eq.13](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S4.E13 "In 4.3 Probability flow and connection to neural ODEs ‣ 4 Solving the reverse SDE ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"), provides the same trajectories given perfectly estimated scores. We provide additional empirical verification on this property in [SectionD.5](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A4.SS5 "D.5 Uniquely identifiable encoding ‣ Appendix D Probability flow ODE ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations").

Efficient sampling  As with neural ODEs, we can sample 𝐱​(0)∼p0similar-to𝐱0subscript𝑝0\\mathbf{x}(0)\\sim p\_{0} by solving [Eq.13](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S4.E13 "In 4.3 Probability flow and connection to neural ODEs ‣ 4 Solving the reverse SDE ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations") from different final conditions 𝐱​(T)∼pTsimilar-to𝐱𝑇subscript𝑝𝑇\\mathbf{x}(T)\\sim p\_{T}. Using a fixed discretization strategy we can generate competitive samples, especially when used in conjuction with correctors ( [Table1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S4.T1 "In 4.2 Predictor-corrector samplers ‣ 4 Solving the reverse SDE ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"), “probability flow sampler”, details in [SectionD.3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A4.SS3 "D.3 Probability flow sampling ‣ Appendix D Probability flow ODE ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")). Using a black-box ODE solver (Dormand & Prince, [1980](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib11 "")) not only produces high quality samples ( [Table2](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S4.T2 "In 4.3 Probability flow and connection to neural ODEs ‣ 4 Solving the reverse SDE ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"), details in [SectionD.4](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A4.SS4 "D.4 Sampling with black-box ODE solvers ‣ Appendix D Probability flow ODE ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")), but also allows us to explicitly trade-off accuracy for efficiency. With a larger error tolerance, the number of function evaluations can be reduced by over 90%percent9090\\% without affecting the visual quality of samples ( [Fig.3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S4.F3 "In 4.3 Probability flow and connection to neural ODEs ‣ 4 Solving the reverse SDE ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")).

![Refer to caption](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456/assets/x3.png)Figure 3: Probability flow ODE enables fast sampling with adaptive stepsizes as the numerical precision is varied (left), and reduces the number of score function evaluations (NFE) without harming quality (middle). The invertible mapping from latents to images allows for interpolations (right).

### 4.4 Architecture improvements

We explore several new architecture designs for score-based models using both VE and VP SDEs (details in [AppendixH](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A8 "Appendix H Architecture improvements ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")), where we train models with the same discrete objectives as in SMLD/DDPM. We directly transfer the architectures for VP SDEs to sub-VP SDEs due to their similarity. Our optimal architecture for the VE SDE, named NCSN++, achieves an FID of 2.45 on CIFAR-10 with PC samplers, while our optimal architecture for the VP SDE, called DDPM++, achieves 2.78.

By switching to the continuous training objective in [Eq.7](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S3.E7 "In 3.3 Estimating scores for the SDE ‣ 3 Score-based generative modeling with SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"), and increasing the network depth, we can further improve sample quality for all models. The resulting architectures are denoted as NCSN++ cont. and DDPM++ cont. in [Table3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S4.T3 "In 4.3 Probability flow and connection to neural ODEs ‣ 4 Solving the reverse SDE ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations") for VE and VP/sub-VP SDEs respectively. Results reported in [Table3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S4.T3 "In 4.3 Probability flow and connection to neural ODEs ‣ 4 Solving the reverse SDE ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations") are for the checkpoint with the smallest FID over the course of training, where samples are generated with PC samplers. In contrast, FID scores and NLL values in [Table2](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S4.T2 "In 4.3 Probability flow and connection to neural ODEs ‣ 4 Solving the reverse SDE ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations") are reported for the last training checkpoint, and samples are obtained with black-box ODE solvers. As shown in [Table3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S4.T3 "In 4.3 Probability flow and connection to neural ODEs ‣ 4 Solving the reverse SDE ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"), VE SDEs typically provide better sample quality than VP/sub-VP SDEs, but we also empirically observe that their likelihoods are worse than VP/sub-VP SDE counterparts. This indicates that practitioners likely need to experiment with different SDEs for varying domains and architectures.

Our best model for sample quality, NCSN++ cont. (deep, VE), doubles the network depth and sets new records for both inception score and FID on unconditional generation for CIFAR-10. Surprisingly, we can achieve better FID than the previous best conditional generative model without requiring labeled data. With all improvements together, we also obtain the first set of high-fidelity samples on CelebA-HQ 1024×1024102410241024\\times 1024 from score-based models (see [SectionH.3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A8.SS3 "H.3 High resolution images ‣ Appendix H Architecture improvements ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")). Our best model for likelihoods, DDPM++ cont. (deep, sub-VP), similarly doubles the network depth and achieves a log-likelihood of 2.99 bits/dim with the continuous objective in [Eq.7](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S3.E7 "In 3.3 Estimating scores for the SDE ‣ 3 Score-based generative modeling with SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"). To our best knowledge, this is the highest likelihood on uniformly dequantized CIFAR-10.

## 5 Controllable generation

The continuous structure of our framework allows us to not only produce data samples from p0subscript𝑝0p\_{0}, but also from p0​(𝐱​(0)∣𝐲)subscript𝑝0conditional𝐱0𝐲p\_{0}(\\mathbf{x}(0)\\mid\\mathbf{y}) if pt​(𝐲∣𝐱​(t))subscript𝑝𝑡conditional𝐲𝐱𝑡p\_{t}(\\mathbf{y}\\mid\\mathbf{x}(t)) is known. Given a forward SDE as in [Eq.5](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S3.E5 "In 3.1 Perturbing data with SDEs ‣ 3 Score-based generative modeling with SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"), we can sample from pt​(𝐱​(t)∣𝐲)subscript𝑝𝑡conditional𝐱𝑡𝐲p\_{t}(\\mathbf{x}(t)\\mid\\mathbf{y}) by starting from pT​(𝐱​(T)∣𝐲)subscript𝑝𝑇conditional𝐱𝑇𝐲p\_{T}(\\mathbf{x}(T)\\mid\\mathbf{y}) and solving a conditional reverse-time SDE:

| --- | --- | --- | --- |
|  | d​𝐱={𝐟​(𝐱,t)−g​(t)2​\[∇𝐱log⁡pt​(𝐱)+∇𝐱log⁡pt​(𝐲∣𝐱)\]}​d​t+g​(t)​d​𝐰¯.d𝐱𝐟𝐱𝑡𝑔superscript𝑡2delimited-\[\]subscript∇𝐱subscript𝑝𝑡𝐱subscript∇𝐱subscript𝑝𝑡conditional𝐲𝐱d𝑡𝑔𝑡d¯𝐰\\displaystyle\\mathrm{d}\\mathbf{x}=\\{\\mathbf{f}(\\mathbf{x},t)-g(t)^{2}\[\\nabla\_{\\mathbf{x}}\\log p\_{t}(\\mathbf{x})+\\nabla\_{\\mathbf{x}}\\log p\_{t}(\\mathbf{y}\\mid\\mathbf{x})\]\\}\\mathrm{d}t+g(t)\\mathrm{d}\\bar{\\mathbf{w}}. |  | (14) |

In general, we can use [Eq.14](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S5.E14 "In 5 Controllable generation ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations") to solve a large family of _inverse problems_ with score-based generative models, once given an estimate of the gradient of the forward process, ∇𝐱log⁡pt​(𝐲∣𝐱​(t))subscript∇𝐱subscript𝑝𝑡conditional𝐲𝐱𝑡\\nabla\_{\\mathbf{x}}\\log p\_{t}(\\mathbf{y}\\mid\\mathbf{x}(t)). In some cases, it is possible to train a separate model to learn the forward process log⁡pt​(𝐲∣𝐱​(t))subscript𝑝𝑡conditional𝐲𝐱𝑡\\log p\_{t}(\\mathbf{y}\\mid\\mathbf{x}(t)) and compute its gradient. Otherwise, we may estimate the gradient with heuristics and domain knowledge. In [SectionI.4](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A9.SS4 "I.4 Solving general inverse problems ‣ Appendix I Controllable generation ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"), we provide a broadly applicable method for obtaining such an estimate without the need of training auxiliary models.

We consider three applications of controllable generation with this approach: class-conditional generation, image imputation and colorization. When 𝐲𝐲\\mathbf{y} represents class labels, we can train a time-dependent classifier pt​(𝐲∣𝐱​(t))subscript𝑝𝑡conditional𝐲𝐱𝑡p\_{t}(\\mathbf{y}\\mid\\mathbf{x}(t)) for class-conditional sampling. Since the forward SDE is tractable, we can easily create training data (𝐱​(t),𝐲)𝐱𝑡𝐲(\\mathbf{x}(t),\\mathbf{y}) for the time-dependent classifier
by first sampling (𝐱​(0),𝐲)𝐱0𝐲(\\mathbf{x}(0),\\mathbf{y}) from a dataset, and then sampling 𝐱​(t)∼p0​t​(𝐱​(t)∣𝐱​(0))similar-to𝐱𝑡subscript𝑝0𝑡conditional𝐱𝑡𝐱0\\mathbf{x}(t)\\sim p\_{0t}(\\mathbf{x}(t)\\mid\\mathbf{x}(0)). Afterwards, we may employ a mixture of cross-entropy losses over different time steps, like [Eq.7](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S3.E7 "In 3.3 Estimating scores for the SDE ‣ 3 Score-based generative modeling with SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"), to train the time-dependent classifier pt​(𝐲∣𝐱​(t))subscript𝑝𝑡conditional𝐲𝐱𝑡p\_{t}(\\mathbf{y}\\mid\\mathbf{x}(t)). We provide class-conditional CIFAR-10 samples in [Fig.4](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S5.F4 "In 5 Controllable generation ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations") (left), and relegate more details and results to [AppendixI](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A9 "Appendix I Controllable generation ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations").

Imputation is a special case of conditional sampling.
Suppose we have an incomplete data point 𝐲𝐲\\mathbf{y} where only some subset, Ω​(𝐲)Ω𝐲\\Omega(\\mathbf{y}) is known. Imputation amounts to sampling from p​(𝐱​(0)∣Ω​(𝐲))𝑝conditional𝐱0Ω𝐲p(\\mathbf{x}(0)\\mid\\Omega(\\mathbf{y})), which we can accomplish using an unconditional model (see [SectionI.2](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A9.SS2 "I.2 Imputation ‣ Appendix I Controllable generation ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")). Colorization is a special case of imputation, except that the known data dimensions are coupled. We can decouple these data dimensions with an orthogonal linear transformation, and perform imputation in the transformed space (details in [SectionI.3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A9.SS3 "I.3 Colorization ‣ Appendix I Controllable generation ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")). [Fig.4](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S5.F4 "In 5 Controllable generation ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations") (right) shows results for inpainting and colorization achieved with unconditional time-dependent score-based models.

## 6 Conclusion

We presented a framework for score-based generative modeling based on SDEs. Our work enables a better understanding of existing approaches, new sampling algorithms, exact likelihood computation, uniquely identifiable encoding, latent code manipulation, and brings new conditional generation abilities to the family of score-based generative models.

While our proposed sampling approaches improve results and enable more efficient sampling, they remain slower at sampling than GANs (Goodfellow et al., [2014](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib14 "")) on the same datasets. Identifying ways of combining the stable learning of score-based generative models with the fast sampling of implicit models like GANs remains an important research direction. Additionally, the breadth of samplers one can use when given access to score functions introduces a number of hyper-parameters. Future work would benefit from improved methods to automatically select and tune these hyper-parameters, as well as more extensive investigation on the merits and limitations of various samplers.

## Appendix

We include several appendices with additional details, derivations, and results.
Our framework allows general SDEs with matrix-valued diffusion coefficients that depend on the state, for which we provide a detailed discussion in [AppendixA](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A1 "Appendix A The framework for more general SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"). We give a full derivation of VE, VP and sub-VP SDEs in [AppendixB](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A2 "Appendix B VE, VP and sub-VP SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"), and discuss how to use them from a practitioner’s perspective in [AppendixC](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A3 "Appendix C SDEs in the wild ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"). We elaborate on the probability flow formulation of our framework in [AppendixD](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A4 "Appendix D Probability flow ODE ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"), including a derivation of the probability flow ODE ( [SectionD.1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A4.SS1 "D.1 Derivation ‣ Appendix D Probability flow ODE ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")), exact likelihood computation ( [SectionD.2](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A4.SS2 "D.2 Likelihood computation ‣ Appendix D Probability flow ODE ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")), probability flow sampling with a fixed discretization strategy ( [SectionD.3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A4.SS3 "D.3 Probability flow sampling ‣ Appendix D Probability flow ODE ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")), sampling with black-box ODE solvers ( [SectionD.4](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A4.SS4 "D.4 Sampling with black-box ODE solvers ‣ Appendix D Probability flow ODE ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")), and experimental verification on uniquely identifiable encoding ( [SectionD.5](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A4.SS5 "D.5 Uniquely identifiable encoding ‣ Appendix D Probability flow ODE ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")). We give a full description of the reverse diffusion sampler in [AppendixE](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A5 "Appendix E Reverse diffusion sampling ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"), the DDPM-type ancestral sampler for SMLD models in [AppendixF](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A6 "Appendix F Ancestral sampling for SMLD models ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"), and Predictor-Corrector samplers in [AppendixG](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A7 "Appendix G Predictor-Corrector samplers ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"). We explain our model architectures and detailed experimental settings in [AppendixH](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A8 "Appendix H Architecture improvements ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"), with 1024×1024102410241024\\times 1024 CelebA-HQ samples therein. Finally, we detail on the algorithms for controllable generation in [AppendixI](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A9 "Appendix I Controllable generation ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"), and include extended results for class-conditional generation ( [SectionI.1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A9.SS1 "I.1 Class-conditional sampling ‣ Appendix I Controllable generation ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")), image inpainting ( [SectionI.2](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A9.SS2 "I.2 Imputation ‣ Appendix I Controllable generation ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")), colorization ( [SectionI.3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A9.SS3 "I.3 Colorization ‣ Appendix I Controllable generation ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")), and a strategy for solving general inverse problems ( [SectionI.4](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A9.SS4 "I.4 Solving general inverse problems ‣ Appendix I Controllable generation ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations")).

## Appendix A The framework for more general SDEs

In the main text, we introduced our framework based on a simplified SDE [Eq.5](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#S3.E5 "In 3.1 Perturbing data with SDEs ‣ 3 Score-based generative modeling with SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations") where the diffusion coefficient is independent of 𝐱​(t)𝐱𝑡\\mathbf{x}(t). It turns out that our framework can be extended to hold for more general diffusion coefficients. We can consider SDEs in the following form:

We additionally introduce sub-VP SDEs, a modification to VP SDEs that often achieves better performance in both sample quality and likelihoods.

The VE SDE always yields a process with exploding variance when t→∞→𝑡t\\to\\infty. In contrast, the VP SDE yields a process with bounded variance. For DDPM, there is no discontinuity issue with the corresponding VP SDE; yet, there are numerical instability issues for training and sampling at t=0𝑡0t=0, due to the vanishing variance of 𝐱​(t)𝐱𝑡\\mathbf{x}(t) as t→0→𝑡0t\\to 0. Therefore, same as the VE SDE, we restrict computation to t∈\[ϵ,1\]𝑡italic-ϵ1t\\in\[\\epsilon,1\] for a small ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\\epsilon>0. For sampling, we choose ϵ=10−3italic-ϵsuperscript103\\epsilon=10^{-3} so that the variance of 𝐱​(ϵ)𝐱italic-ϵ\\mathbf{x}(\\epsilon) in VP SDE matches the variance of 𝐱1subscript𝐱1\\mathbf{x}\_{1} in DDPM; for training and likelihood computation, we adopt ϵ=10−5italic-ϵsuperscript105\\epsilon=10^{-5} which empirically gives better results.

Figure 5: Discrete-time perturbation kernels and our continuous generalizations match each other almost exactly. (a) compares the variance of perturbation kernels for SMLD and VE SDE; (b) compares the scaling factors of means of perturbation kernels for DDPM and VP SDE; and (c) compares the variance of perturbation kernels for DDPM and VP SDE.

As a sanity check for our SDE generalizations to SMLD and DDPM, we compare the perturbation kernels of SDEs and original discrete Markov chains in [Fig.5](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A3.F5 "In Appendix C SDEs in the wild ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"). The SMLD and DDPM models both use N=1000𝑁1000N=1000 noise scales. For SMLD, we only need to compare the variances of perturbation kernels since means are the same by definition. For DDPM, we compare the scaling factors of means and the variances. As demonstrated in [Fig.5](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A3.F5 "In Appendix C SDEs in the wild ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"), the discrete perturbation kernels of original SMLD and DDPM models align well with perturbation kernels derived from VE and VP SDEs.

For sub-VP SDEs, we use exactly the same β​(t)𝛽𝑡\\beta(t) as VP SDEs. This leads to the following perturbation kernel

|     |     |     |     |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
|  | p0​t​(𝐱​(t)∣𝐱​(0))=𝒩​(𝐱​(t);e−14​t2​(β¯max−β¯min)−12​t​β¯min​𝐱​(0),\[1−e−12​t2​(β¯max−β¯min)−t​β¯min\]2​𝐈),t∈\[0,1\].p\_{0t}(\\mathbf{x}(t)\\mid\\mathbf{x}(0))\\\<br>=\\mathcal{N}\\left(\\mathbf{x}(t);e^{-\\frac{1}{4}t^{2}(\\bar{\\beta}\_{\\text{max}}-\\bar{\\beta}\_{\\text{min}})-\\frac{1}{2}t\\bar{\\beta}\_{\\text{min}}}\\mathbf{x}(0),\[1-e^{-\\frac{1}{2}t^{2}(\\bar{\\beta}\_{\\text{max}}-\\bar{\\beta}\_{\\text{min}})-t\\bar{\\beta}\_{\\text{min}}}\]^{2}\\mathbf{I}\\right),\\quad t\\in\[0,1\]. |  | (34) |

We also restrict numerical computation to the same interval of \[ϵ,1\]italic-ϵ1\[\\epsilon,1\] as VP SDEs.

Empirically, we observe that smaller ϵitalic-ϵ\\epsilon generally yields better likelihood values for all SDEs. For sampling, it is important to use an appropriate ϵitalic-ϵ\\epsilon for better Inception scores and FIDs, although samples across different ϵitalic-ϵ\\epsilon look visually the same to human eyes.

## Appendix D Probability flow ODE

### D.1 Derivation

The idea of probability flow ODE is inspired by Maoutsa et al. ( [2020](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib32 "")), and one can find the derivation of a simplified case therein. Below we provide a derivation for the fully general ODE in [Eq.17](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A1.E17 "In Appendix A The framework for more general SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"). We consider the SDE in [Eq.15](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#A1.E15 "In Appendix A The framework for more general SDEs ‣ Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations"), which possesses the following form:

| --- | --- | --- |
|  | d​𝐱=𝐟​(𝐱,t)​d​t+𝐆​(𝐱,t)​d​𝐰,d𝐱𝐟𝐱𝑡d𝑡𝐆𝐱𝑡d𝐰\\displaystyle\\mathrm{d}\\mathbf{x}=\\mathbf{f}(\\mathbf{x},t)\\mathrm{d}t+\\mathbf{G}(\\mathbf{x},t)\\mathrm{d}\\mathbf{w}, |  |

where 𝐟​(⋅,t):ℝd→ℝd:𝐟⋅𝑡→superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑\\mathbf{f}(\\cdot,t):\\mathbb{R}^{d}\\to\\mathbb{R}^{d} and 𝐆​(⋅,t):ℝd→ℝd×d:𝐆⋅𝑡→superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑𝑑\\mathbf{G}(\\cdot,t):\\mathbb{R}^{d}\\to\\mathbb{R}^{d\\times d}. The marginal probability density pt​(𝐱​(t))subscript𝑝𝑡𝐱𝑡p\_{t}(\\mathbf{x}(t)) evolves according to Kolmogorov’s forward equation (Fokker-Planck equation) (Øksendal, [2003](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2011.13456#bib.bib35 ""))

| --- | --- | --- | --- |
